comments:
These failures occurr intermitently:

* testDeferredBreakpoints

java.lang.NullPointerException
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.core.DeferredBreakpointTests.testDeferredBreakpoints(DeferredBreakpointTests.java:85)
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.DebugSuite$1.run(DebugSuite.java:53)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:534)

* testInactiveStepFilter

junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Receiving type name should have been 'StepFilterTwo' but was <unknown receiving type>
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.core.StepFilterTests.testInactiveStepFilter(StepFilterTests.java:72)
at org.eclipse.jdt.debug.tests.DebugSuite$1.run(DebugSuite.java:53)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:534)

Methods in JDI thread that call #computeStackFrames() are actually using the "fStackFranmes" list, in potentially unsynchronized methods. They use the underlying list rather than a copy. Methods using this call should be updated to be thread safe.

For now, I've updated #getStackFrames() and #getTopStackFrame() to be synchronized, but we should examine all uses.

Further investiation shows that the thread that has suspended at the "next" breakpoint is terminated when we ask for the top frame. It appears to be the correct frame, so I'm not sure why it has (or thinks it has) terminated.

It appears the once and a while the VM disconnects when asked for stack frames. When this happens, the target is "cleaned up" and threads are marked as terminated, causing the thread to have no frames.

It's not clear why the VM sometimes randomly disconnects in this case. We are performing a rapid succession of suspend/resumes thru a list of breakpoints.

This is a sample stack trace when the disconnect occurrs:

State info:
   isDisconnected: true
   Thread isTerminated: true
   Target isTerminated: false
To reduce contention on the target, I've modified the test to not register the launch. This avoids source lookup competing with the test.
Modified "step filter" tests to not register launch too.
Marking as works for me... these tests appear to be passing regularly now.
